Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:You can share files with someone if you have a connection to a what? Choices:  A: freeway B: radio C: wires D: computer network E: electrical circuit<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>if(input == "wire") :<n>    print("You can share files with some one on a computer network by wires")<n>else:<n>    print("You cannot share files with some one who is on the computer network by wires because you don't have a computer network")<n>```<n>### Except:<n>In the code below the else statement is commented out and instead of getting an answer of "I cannot share files with some on the computer network by wire because there not a computer network." the else statement does make it print. Can you explain what is happening?  <n>```python<n>if inputs = "wire":<n>    i = 5<n><n>    print ("I like icecream")<n>else :<n>    print ("I cannot share files with each other on the computer network by  wire because they are on other computer networks. <n>```<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The else statement makes it print because we did not assign i any values. Then when we execute the code without values it print even though we tried to make i = 5.<n><n>### Expected Output:<n>```python<n>print ("You can share file with someone if you are on a computer network by wire)<n>```<n><n><n>##### [Link to solution](https://www.codechef.com/APRIL22/solutions/RFGK4Y)<n>

If the element does not exist, the expression will return true.<n><n>```html<n>var listCount = 0;<n>var testElement = "row 3,value 1:ID";<n><n>if (testElement in thisList) {<n>    listCount++; <n>    var listIncluded = returnListContainsObject(testElement);<n>} else {<n>    listCount = 0<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Insturction<n><n>### Demo:<n>Write a statement that contains 2 expressions to return the name of each element in the list with a value of less than 1.<n><n>### Input List:<n>```<n>row 1,value 1:1.5<n>row 2,value 1:5.7<n>row 3,value less than 1:0.3<n>```<n><n>## Expected Output:<n>```<n>0.3 value is less than 1<n>row

Choices:  A: names B: words C: naval D: bladders E: feelings<n><n>### Response:		What's peace? Do we all want it and is it the same for everyone? Peace comes from a number of sources; people, nations, religions, etc. The term 'peace' as we usually use it, includes the cessation of open warfare or hostility, with emphasis on the 'cold war', or what was seen as the 'danger' posed by the USSR to the West, between the 1940's and 1990's. The hippy might have had a word that is more comprehensive, yet not the word used by other people.<n><n>### Input:"Who would want to be in a group with you?" Demonstration:A person wants to be in a group. Choices:  A:"Someone who knows everything" B: "Someone who's like me" C: "Nobody" D:"A good dancer" E:"I can't help it"<n>Answer: C: "Nobdy"<n>Output:"You're a real loser aren't you?" response:I understand the question 'why do you think you would have trouble being in a group with me?' I feel a sense of inferiority and would like to resolve this sense of inferiority, although I know this doesn't help. It is unfair to judge everyone on the basis of a single trait. We are the sum of all our past experiences and are what we are now. I try not to believe people who tell me they know everything or are like me. I prefer to believe people who believe in the good in others even though they may misjudge.<n><n>### Response:(Instruction: Choose one of the following statements to respond to)<n><n>##### A:When you're young, you are less likely to eat because of age?<n>B: When young, eating is more likely to get in the way of other activities?<n>C: Young people eat less when the workload increases?<n>D: When young, not enough people think about food?<n><n>##### Choose one response.<n><n>Output:(Answer A,B,C,D)<n><n>### Instructions:<n>**Question:** Why do you think there might not be much time for sleep?<n>**Answer:** (One answer per question)<n><n>**Answer:** I often sleep less than I would like.

Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:What will telling many people about an embarrassing situation lead to? Choices:  A: notoriety B: emotional distress C: riot D: bad dreams E: annoyance<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Write a **block of code** that demonstrates an answer to the previous question. The code should print the answer to the previous question **as a string**.<n>### Notes:<n>* The block of code must be indented properly using either tabs or spaces<n>* Line break characters may not be used within the block of code<n>  <n>### Code Example:<n>```swift<n>var answer = "D"<n>```<n><n>### Test Cases:<n>|Answer|Code Example|<n>|------|-------------|<n>|A|`Your answer would be found at oil refinieries.`|<n>|B|`Your answer would not be of use if you are thirst.`|<n>|C|`Your answer would involve a plumbing task.`|<n>|D|`Your answer would have to do with accomplishing.`|<n>|E|`Your answer would also be found with water fountains.`|<n><n>### Exercise:<n>```swift<n>// Demonstration:Answer the following multiplechoice question.<n>// Instruction:Answer the followin multiple choice question.<n>// You decide to write a few lines here<n>// of code on how to do this.<n>// If you wish you may begin by defining a variable that will be used in <n>// the code.<n>```<n><n>## Challenge:<n><n>Please find me at one of these places.<n><n>### Facebook<n>https://www.facebook.com/dick.brown<n><n>## About Dick Brown<n>https://github.com/djb01/<n>

Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:James needed a garage because he spent a lot of money on what? Choices:  A: bike B: downtown C: building D: tool storage E: car<n><n>### Response:		James needed a garge because he spened money on a car.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:The woman picked from an apple tree while surrounded by other trees, where was she? Choices:  A: illinois B: woods C: new york D: indiana E: farmer's market<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input for the above question:<n><n>### Answer for the above question:Illinois -> woods -> new york -> indiana -> farmer's market -> apple tree.<n><n><n>## Task description<n><n>> ## Why this works<n>> All of the answers should be `tree`.<n>><n>> > ## Challenge<n>> > Make a program that will find the correct output for the two inputs listed in this task.<n>> > In order to win this challenge, the program's output must be exactly what the teacher wrote.<n>> ><n>> > ## Instructions<n>> > Write a program that tests two inputs to see if it will get back a true (true = "Tree") or false (true = "not tree").<n>> > Below is a picture of what your program would have to do for the two different inputs. Your program would have to take **Apple Tree** and return **Tree**.<n>> ><n><n>## Instruction:<n><n>## Demonstration:

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:Where is a good place to get a ball? Choices:  A: kitchen B: child's hand C: street D: toy store E: soccer game<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Comment:<n><n>## Solution<n><n>\begin{code}<n>function f(s) { if (s === 'water') return 'A'; else return 'D'; }<n><n>console.log(f('Show me your water fountain.'));<n>console.log(s => f(s));<n>\end{code}<n><n>Answered here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22758827/is-there-any-way-to-do-multiple-conditional-statements-using-if-else<n><n>Answer: This problem is probably not a good way to teach recursion. The logic can be solved without recursion. Just use an array and index it correctly. This was also answered on another post but I don't know how to copy the code and post it here.<n><n>\begin{blockquote}<n>You also don't really need recursion here as the conditions themselves already lead to the correct answer or don't.<n><n>\begin{"question":  """What happens to your<n>body temperature when you run?<n><n>Answer: A:  body temperature increases. This question can be answered<n>using<n>the conditions:<n>\begin{itemize}<n>\item running<n>\item body temperature<n>\end{itemize}<n><n>\end{blockquote}<n><n>\begin{pre}<n>`const f= (s)=> { let result=''; if (s=='running') { result='A:body<n>temperature increases.'; } else if (s=='body temperature') {<n>result='B:body<n>temperature'; } else if (<n>s=='heat' || s=='warm' || s=='hot') { result='C:heat, warm or<n>hot'; }<n>return result; };`<n>\end{pre}<n><n>\begin{`body temperature`<n>`running`<n>`heat`<n>`warm`<n>`hot`<n>`A:body<n>temperatures increases.`<n>`B:body<n>temperatures.`<n>`C:heats, warm,hot.`<n>`D:wrong s not in any list` \strong{`A:body<n>temperaturer increases.`}`<n>\end{code}"

Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: bee hive B: england C: castle D: deck of cards E: chess game<n><n>### Response:		<n>B: Bees do not always have a queen, the queen is a secondary role which takes on all responsibilities of the larve<n><n>### Input : Where will you not find a pink flower? Choices:  B: blue Flower  A: red flower E: none of them C: yellow flower D: white flower<n><n>### Response : C: yellow flower. When it is not time to plant spring vegetable and when the fall vegetables have not been planted then there is nothing to be planted.<n><n><n>```<n>#! /bin/sh<n><n>#The instruction contains three statements. They are in three separate lines.<n><n>#First, the "Instruction" statement is read, the "Task" statement(s) are read,<n>#and then the "Input" statement is read. "Response" is the statement where<n>#the actual completion of the instructions takes place. Note that the "Demostration"<n>#statement does not contain any words that the instruction tells the program to put in <n>#the "Response" statement.<n><n>#When the program is executed, it will ask the user 7 questions.<n>#It will then print the person's answer. The program has been developed to print with<n>#the echo command, however this feature does not have to be used. The user will<n>#receive 7 guesses, and it will print the question twice. If the program receives the<n>#answer (as described by the "Input" statement) correct, it will give a short message. If the<n>#program receives an incorrect answer (as described by the task statement), it will give a message<n>#that the response is incorrect as requested by the "Instructions". The program<n>#will then prompt the user for new input.<n><n><n>printf "Instruction"<n>printf "Task"<n>printf "Input"<n>printf "Response"<n>while true; do<n><n><n>	case "$1" in<n>		Instructions)<n>			echo "Answer the following multiple choice Question"<n>			echo 1. Answers A, B, C or D. You may find this instruction and the <n>			echo response by visiting the source. The source can be found by <n>			#  using the "cat" command.<n>			echo  2. Demonstration-

I feel like the instruction and demonstration are too similar, and I'm trying to figure out why they even need to be the same.<n><n>Comment: The instructions could be left the same, but it would make sense if the actual demonstration is different for every question. If the instructions were the just same as the demonstration, one would be getting the question/answer backwards most of the time.  That said, I don't see why it's necessary to use the demonstration.  I would suggest that all you need to do is give a sample 'correct' answer for the input 'question' and answer options (the demonstration step).<n><n>Comment: Okay, let me try breaking it down to the basic. Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:A common saying, Sam thought, was to go forth, also this. Choices:  A: reverse B: backwards C: back and D: back and E: tally back<n><n>### Response:		C: back and<n>---<n><n>### Instructions:<n>**This task is asking for one or more ideas.** <n><n>### Democracy Voting:<n>- [ ] A ____________ is anyone who participates in a democracy.<n>- [ ] Citizens elect their ____________ to represent them in a legislative body.<n>- [ ] The citizens vote directly for their government officials in a _____________.<n>- [ ] They can also vote for a __________ if a position doesn’t exist.<n>- [X] Everyone has the same vote.<n><n>### Response Question:<n>What makes the United States a democracy?<n><n>---<n><n>## Task:<n><n>### Demarcation:<n>**What does it mean when someone is called a “demarcation?”**<n><n>### Demand:<n>**What does “demand” mean? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:What might someone do who is having fun? Choices:  A: being happy B: glee C: smoke D: stress relief E: may laugh<n><n>### Response:		The answer is C.<n><n>### Input 1:<n>The last time I had a colonoscopy, I had a choice between a camera that was 1/10th or 1/8th inch long, and I had to decide which one I thought would be the least intrusive. I chose the 1/8th-inch probe, and was a bit disappointed to learn that the doctor didn't have the 1/8-inch camera on hand. But it turned out to be no big deal, though I didn't realize this until the nurse told me afterward. The main thing is of course that no matter which one I choose, my body should be just fine afterward.<n><n>### Response 1:<n>There seems to be no difference between the cameras, because both the 1/10-inch and 1/8- inch camera are still too big. The last time the nurse told me that no matter what camera I choose, my end will be fine or without side-effects. This means that there would still be a need for surgery, even if I choose the smaller end.<n><n>### Authored By: @amg0222/Rosslyn Y.

Choices:  A: shelf B: desktop C: cabinet D: kitchen E: cupboard<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I recommend the shelf. The coffee mug has just emptied it's container for your use for today but before you place it in a cabinet it must be placed on the shelf first.<n>Clean the mug, then place it back on the shelf. This is where you keep all your dishes and cups.

Taken to a location where people wear white lab coats, the monkey will most likely be taken to a research laboratory. A research lab typically contains cages and people that dress in white coats. The researchers will interact with the monkey. The monkey will need food and water. A trained monkey used for research is often referred to as a lab rat.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:Where does a shadow usually appear? Choices:  A: suface of moon B: building C: bridge D: ground E: bright light<n><n>### Response:		A: suface of earth<n> <n>### Notes:<n>* The problem is described using multiple choice. There are five sets of choices. The description will have a choice of some kind.<n>* You must choose the _correct_ (not necessarily the most popular) option from those given.<n>* All of the questions share a theme. Some questions are straightforward and some questions require some creativity to answer (the answers are not always obvious)<n>* An "A" or correct answer has the abbreviation "A/C". ("A" is plural for "answer".)<n><n>### Example:<n>The instruction reads,<n><n>Write a response that is the abbreviation for "water is wet".<n><n>Let's write the response:<n>water\is\wet (A/C)<n> <n>## A few notes on format:<n><n>* The instructions will be in bold, so you can quickly tell if you are being asked to read or if an answer is being requested.<n>* An answer is always in italics and surrounded by square brackets.<n> <n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Work<n>2.  Resting<n>3. Tiredness<n>4. Accomplishing<n>5. Momentum<n><n>#### Choice: "C"<n><n>>**_B_**<n>><n>>"C" because they are not tired, they don't have an accomplishment, and they are not building momentum.<n><n>```python<n>A = False<n>B = False<n>C = False<n>D = False<n>E = False<n>input = ["C", "B", "E", "E", "A"]<n>for i in input:<n>    a = [a for a in [A, B, C, D]][0]<n>    print(i, ": ",a)<n>'''<n>A: "C"<n>B: "B"<n>C: "C"<n>D: "D"<n>E: "E"<n>```<n><n>#### Input:Where might I find pens witha company logo?<n>1. A: office<n>2. B: on a penceil<n>3. C:write sentences on paper<n>4. D:school<n>5. E:backpack<n><n>#### Choice:"D"<n><n>>**_"A_"**<n>><n>>"D" because it is in office<n><n>```python<n>a = [a for a, b in zip(input, [A, B, c, D, E])]<n>print(a)<n>input.close()<n>'''<n>[3, "A", 2, "C", "D", 5, "E"]<n>```<n><n>#### Response: Where could you findsome plumbingwould not be of use toyou if you arethirsty?<n>>**_A_"**<n>> <n>>"A" because it is an office<n><n>```python  <n>input = ["A", "C", "B

This was a good exercise for me for the same reason: I didn't know that they were the same beforehand :)<n><n>Input: The person who was reading this sentence was writing it. Choices:  A 1: books B 2: bats C 3: pencils D 4: pads E 5: scissors <n>Answer: A: books<n><n>Input: The pen was used by the young boy, who wrote the words. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:What is a fast but expensive way to send small cargo? Choices:  A: airplane B: ship's hold C: boat D: truck E: train<n><n>### Response:		<n>I believe the fast but expensive way to ship small cargo is a plane. Air transportation is very fast but expensive. If the cargo is of high value, it is well worth the high expense of air freight. A ship's hold can carry large cargo, but it is slow as the cargo is heavy and requires a lot of energy to bring it onboard. A boat and a truck cannot carry the same weight as a cargo planes.<n><n>### Response (Part 2)<n>Because an airplane can carry a large amount of cargo, if it is of high value, the high cost for the airfare is a small price to pay. With ships, and the weight of the cargo, the price is cheap for this mode of transportation. Both a boat and a truck are useful, but slow.

The computer might need a paper file so it can be stored in a computer file, but it is not an office furniture. A desk needs paper to organize papers on and it becomes a part of an office furniture.  <n>* **More Details**:<n>  * Desk: need paper files. <n><n><n>### Input<n>A person in Japan will probably find which of the following the most difficult? In an essay, I can have an objective answer, but in my case, I have to be more objective when answering the multiple choice questions.<n>When I do the multiple choice questions, I have to be able to use the clues that were given in the question and think of an immediate answer, without taking the time to understand the question. I have to come to a conclusion and decide.<n><n>### Response #2<n><n>To determine when it is time to give up, you could consider several things. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:What is KFC who serves chicken? Choices:  A: fast food restaurant B: plate C: bowl D: freezer E: oven<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Reference:<n>You will use the `Answer()` method which includes a single element `question`, which should be what the user asked. In addition, it requires an array of the choices as the method returns the result as an `array`.<n><blockquote class="code"><n><p> Answer(input, choices);<br><n>- Question: string<br><n>- Choices: array of strings<br><n></p><n><p> return Choice</p><n><n></blockquote><n><n>### Hint:<n>The question is:<n>> What does "Ask the user what they would like to drink." mean?<n><n>Answer: I created in the beginning a class called `Question` and a function inside this class called `answer`, that will check if what was said by the user is the correct answer or not. If it is, I just ask for the next question, else I do what ever was ask.<n><code><n>  class Question {<n>  private answer;<n>    function answer(input, choices){<n>        if(answer ==  choices) {<n>         nextQuest();<n>        }else{<n>         answer = false;<n>        }<n>    }<n>  }<n><n>  function nextQuest(){<n>   answer('Hello','A: Hello/B: goodbye/C: hi')<n>  }<n><n></code><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:What prevents someone from getting sleep at night? Choices:  A: relax B: dreams C: have nightmares D: restlessness E: snore<n><n>### Response:		Answer with an explanation.<n><n>### Input<n><n>What prevents someone from getting enough sleep at night?Choices:  A: anxiety B: relaxation C: having nightmares D: being restless E: snoring <n><n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: B: Relaxation stops someone from getting sleep.<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>Example: A: A person’s anxiety will stop them from getting sleep.<n>B: A person’s state of relaxation before they go to bed will stop them from getting enough sleep.<n>C: A person’s feelings of stress prevent them from getting sleep. <n><n>Example: A person’s dreams do not usually allow a person to get enough sleep. They tend to wake up and they will stop a person from getting sleep if a person thinks about it.<n>D: A person’s restlessness could make them not get sleep because they could not slow their minds enough to allow them to sleep. <n><n>This is because of the amount of stress they have on them causing their mind to think and do everything at once.<n><n>Example: E: A person’s snoring will prevent them from getting enough sleep if they snore too loudly.<n><n>#### Hint:<n>Remember to always put your code (suggestion) into the same category you place the input. The category that is suggested should be the name of the category that you use for the input.<n><n>* Category can be one of the following:<n><n>* Category: Place category name here<n><n>* Suggestion: Place suggestion here<n><n>#### Check your code<n><n>Did you do everything correctly and follow our instruction?<n><n>#### Try different inputs<n>Did you get different outputs?<n><n>### Checks<n><n>Did you do each task correctly?<n><n>Did you follow our instruction?<n>

Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:The artist didn't use many colors to capture the view, he was famous for his very plain what? Choices:  A: landscape B: east side C: countryside D: middle america E: georgia<n><n>### Response:		C: countrysie<n><n>### What is the difference between "A lot" vs "A whole bunch"<n>While they both mean a large quantity of something, "A lot of" means that there's more, more than there is, and "a bunch" actually means there's less.<n><n>### Exact definition of "A lot"<n>"A lot of people went" ---> The large number of people went. "Did you see that car? It was a lot of car!" ---> It was A LOT of car!"<n><n>### Examples of a lot of:<n>The company had a lot of people working there.<n>There were a lot of people there for dinner.<n>The store had a lot of stuff!<n><n>### Explanation of "A bunch"<n>A bunch means less because it refers to a whole bunch of something, like a lot.<n><n>### "A lot" vs. "a bunch" Examples:<n>"Wow! I like this place a bunch!" ---> I like this place a whole bunch!<n>"I'm going to the basketball game tonight, but i'm not bringing a lot." --->  I'm going to the baseketball game tonight, but I'm not bringing a BUNCH.<n>There is a BUNCH of carrots at the sidewalk sale. -- > There is A LOT of carrots at that sale.<n>There's a SLEW of cars in that parking lot. --- > There's a BUNCH of cars in that parkinign lot.<n>

Choices:  A: diary B: city C: bible D: graffiti E: labyrinth<n><n>### Response:		<n>- What is the question?<n>---<n><n>- I would find plumbing that is not usable when I'm thirsty and can be found in oil refineries.<n>-<n>- I would find a person beginning their work while being in their house but not accomplishing anything.<n>-<n>- To find pens with a company logos, would be at a retail store.<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Complete the task below.<n><n>### Task:<n>- Create a text file and use this template to input information: ```C:\Users\username\desktop\test.txt```<n>	1. [Write this text]<n>	2. [Write this text again]<n>	3. [Write this different text]<n>	4. [Write this different and long text]<n>- I have read the text that does not have a question.  <n>- I will try to complete the task.  <n>- I can do it if you give me enough time to focus.  <n>- I did not find the complete task in this file.  <n>- I am not allowed to open new files.<n><n>---<n>### Answer:<n>Write a program in the python <n>- ```import readline```<n>- ```import getpass```<n>- ```import time```<n>- ```import os```<n>- ```import sys```<n>- ```import re```<n><n>---<n><n>##### Task 1:<n><n>- Write a single line of code that prints  "Hello there!"  <n>-  To do that, you will need to import a library. Which library is needed here? Write your answer here.  <n>	```from readline import get_completions```<n>	```from getpass import getpass```<n>	```from time import sleep```<n>	```from os import listdir```<n>	```from sys import argv```<n>	```from re import search```<n>	```from readlines import readline```<n>---<n><n>###### Write the code on the following line:  `print("Hello there!")`<n><n>######  [Optional]  <n>- Write a single character line of code that prints "Hi."  <n>-  To write it, you will again need to import a library or function.  <n>- Which library or function do you need here? Choices: D: on the bus E: waiting for the bus F: not a bus G: the bus station<n><n>**Example: A: not a bus station**<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:Why is grooming often recommended to greasy teens? Choices:  A: neatness B: selfishness C: mistakes D: cleanliness E: satisfaction<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>#!/usr/bin/env python3<n># -*- coding: utf-8 -*-<n><n>response = ("answer to {}")<n><n><n>if input == "Where could you find some plumbering that wouldnt be of use to you" \<n>        "if you are thirsty?" \<n>        "Choices:{A}, {B}, {C}, ({D}), {E}":<n>    answer = choice(["A: oil refineries", "B: wall", "C: show", "D: own home", "E: water fountain"])<n>elif input == "When a person is beginning work " \<n>        "what aren't they not doing yet?" \<n>        "Choicese:{A}, {B }, {C}, ({D}), {E} ":" \<n>        answer = choice(["D:  accomplishing", "A: working", "C: tiredness", "B: resting", "E: momentum"])<n><n>elif input = "Where might I find pens with the companylogo?" \<n>        " Choice A:{}, {B}, {c}, ({D}), ({E}), E: backpack " :<n>    answer = choice([ "A: Office", "E: backpack", "C: write sentences on paper", "B: write sentences on paper"])<n>    <n><n>response = response.format(answer)<n>print(response)<n>```<n><n>### Feedback<n><n>Given that the first instruction requires three answers, <n>the second requires six, and the third requires one, I decided to add in the following<n>in line before the line of responses is generated.<n><n>```python<n>num_answers = int(input())<n>```<n><n>I didn't think this was a good solution, so I decided to use a for loop<n><n>### Suggestions<n><n>I used a dictionary to get the number of answer choices that are allowed.<n><n>```python'import'<n>num_answers=dict(A = 3, B = 6, C = 1)<n>```<n><n>I felt that this was unnecessary<n><n>```python'for'=num_answers.items()<n>answer = ("{} to {} Choices:{}{}, {} ").format(input,num_answers[input],num_answers[choice

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:The man went to clown college, he had always want to run away with the what? Choices:  A: circus B: carnival C: surprise D: spoons E: party<n><n>### Response:		The man went to clowns college, he was always wanting to dance for a circus. (C)

Choices:  A: store B: classroom C: backpack D: cabinet E: teacher<n><n>### Response:		A: store<n><n>### Input-Response Format<n><n>The structure of this task is input-response format.<n><n>In this task, we only need to make sure that the response is 1.) a complete response and 2.) that the input is a complete question followed by correct choice for the question.<n><n>## Assessment<n><n>This task is assessed by checking that the response is present and the response sentence is appropriated.<n><n>### Guidelines<n><n>We need to follow the task structure to fulfill this task.<n><n>## Notes<n><n>### Input<n><n>|  |  |<n>| :--- | :--- |<n>| **Question** | Where could you find some pencils? |<n>| **Corresponding Choice** | Classroom/Books |<n><n>### Response Structure<n><n>We need to check to ensure the following:<n><n>- All the input has been inputted.<n><n>- The response is present.<n><n>- The appropriate response has been picked.<n>

Choices:  A: empathy B: anxiety C: knowlege D: falling down E: hear things<n><n>### Response:		Answer the question using the same words.<n><n>### Solution:<n>Input: Where is the main street in the city where the police have to work? Choices: <n>A: main street <n>B: side street <n>C: park <n>D: school <n>E:[removed]<n><n>[removed]<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>Answer questions with the same phrases.<n>```<n>### Instruction<n>Write a program that takes as input a string of five words and an input string and outputs a new string. The new string is to be built from the original in a way so as to make you think of the two together. Write the resulting string with the original string in italics with a slash between. When the two are combined in to one, use the same syntax used in the original example, only with an apostrophe or a quotation mark: “A good example of writing a good introduction to a technical document is to…”<n><n>### Instructions for Demonstration<n>Example: “A good example is to…”<n>```<n>### Demontration<n>```<n>Input: <n>- the first word entered is the verb <n>- the second word is "I" <n>- the third word is what you want to be with me <n>- the fourth word is "here/there" <n>- the fifth word is "by"<n><n>Output:<n>-“Are you here/there by/in/with? /by/with/in/here?” <n><n>### Input (Sample)<n>```<n>Input:<n>- "Is that your friend?"<n>```<n><n>## Solution<n>```<n>Input:Where is your friend?<n>"Is that your friend?" /by/with/here/?<n><n>Input:Where is that friend of yours?<n>"Where is that friend of your's?"<n>Are they near here?<n><n>Input:Who's that you're with?<n>"Who's that?", he said.<n>Yes, the person in front of you.<n><n>Input: Who is that guy you're going with?<n>"Is that the guy you're traveling with?", asked a cop.<n>No, not him.<n>```<n><n>**Instruction:Answer**<n>A good example is to<n>ask the question.<n>```<n># Example<n>-“A good example”<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:What is a good result of losing weight? Choices:  A: increased energy B: healthier C: loose skin D: beauty E: death<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple answer questions.<n><n>### Inputs:What are some ways you might tell someone is thirsty?<n><n>### Answer:There are so many ways, you can tell someone is thirst without saying a word. You can give them an eye contact, make funny faces to make them laugh, play with them to make the conversation.<n><n>### Response 2:Answer the following multiple answers question.<n><n>##Inputs:What three things can you do if your car battery runs down while you're away from home? Where are you?<n>Answers:The three things you can do if your car battery ran down while you're home is: 1: Don't push the button on your key ignition just incase. 2: If your spare tire is full, you may fill it with the spare and push on the button with the hope of starting the engine. 3: If the spare is empty, you have to push the button on the ignition several times and make lots of small motions which helps the car’s battery to start up.<n><n>### Questions:Where does water typically come from?<n><n>##Answer:Water can come in form of rainfall and it is used from river.<n><n>### Q:Why is water an essential item to have at home?<n><n>##A: Without water or water as an essencialitem,our body will not able to do some of the activities normally performed.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:What will happen to skin pinched in something? Choices:  A: feel cold B: feel pressure C: feel bumpy D: itches E: feel clammy<n><n>### Response:		What will happen to the skin of someone who has pressed their finger into a penny?<n>Answer: B: feel pressure<n><n>### Input:(This response does not show the correct answer to the question.)<n><n>What will happen to a pen that is left out in the rain?<n><n>### Expected Response:<n>It will collect water.<n><n>### Answer:<n>A pen is a valuable commodity inside the office. What if it were to get water on it?<n><n>A pen is a plastic tube with liquid ink. The purpose of this liquid is to have an easy-to-use tool for writing. If this pen were to get water on its surface, it would no longer be able to write upon paper. The water would be a hindrance in this endeavor instead of an asset.<n>

Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:What is a person who is well educated? Choices:  A: illiterate B: knowledgable C: own house D: have enough food E: meet expectations<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Demand - Who might I find pens with company name and logo on?<n><n>Answer - Someone who is well educated.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Demand: What do crab shells and coconut fibre have in common?<n><n>Answer: Both have hard parts (or shells) with soft fleshy part inside.<n><n>### Question<n><n>Demand  What will happen if you touch hot iron to copper pipe?<n><n>Answer  Electricity will pass through iron to cause a shock.<n><n>### Task<n><n>Supplies - What supplies do I need for my science project?<n><n>Answer To make a compass, you need a piece of iron, a pointed needle, and soft iron, a magnet, and a piece of paper with a number of parallel lines on it.<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>Demand/Supplies - What supplies are needed to make an iron wrench?<n><n>Answer  You need a magnet and soft iron, or ferromagnetic metal, such as iron or steel.<n><n>### Other examples<n><n>## Demand<n>Give a description of what they are describing, for example cats have four legs and can climb trees. Answer: Four legged animal, can climb trees.<n><n>## How?<n>Describe what they have just described, giving extra information, for example, "cats often sit on the ground but they are capable of standing." Answer: Something like (not a good answer): "a four legged animal which can climb trees and is capable of standing but prefers to sit on the ground".<n><n>### Task 1<n><n>Input: Who can play video games after 12 in the morning?<n><n>Answer: Children who live in the house.<n><n>Input: How might you find a person who wears glasses?<n><n>Answer: A person who has trouble seeing and who wears glasses.<n><n>Input: Where do you find someone?<n><n>Output: They can be found anywhere.<n><n>### Output<n>How? Output: They wear glasses and can see well.<n>

Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:The president had to make a decision regarding the hate attack on his country, what did he do? So since it is already half past 5, the question asks about going to the picnic in 2 more hours, since it is already too late to go.<n><n>### Your Input: The following sentence asks where something is located.<n>Where would you go to get a book of tunes used to play the piano?<n><n>### Your Demostration:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:Where would someone learn to play an upright piano? Choices:  A: music room B: music store C: music class D: medium E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: You could learn to play the upright piano in a music room.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>import re<n>from nltk.tokenize import sent_tokenize<n>import nltk<n>import ast<n>import glob<n><n>print"Where would someone learn to"<n><n>searchQuery = input()<n><n>#print "enter "<n>tokenizeText = sent_tokenize(searchQuery)<n>print tokenizeText<n><n><n>for item in tokenizeText:<n>print item<n><n>def wordFilter(text):<n>	text =text.string<n><n>	if "plumbing" in text:<n>		return "oil refineries"<n><n>	if "thirsty" in text :<n>		return "water fountain"<n><n>	if"beginning" in text:<n><n>	a = "accomplishing"<n>	return a<n><n>	if "work" in text :<n><n>	b = "working"<n>	return b<n><n>	if"school" in text :<n> <n>	c = ""<n>	return c<n><n>	if "momentum" in text:<n> <n>	d = "accomplish"<n>	return d<n><n><n><n><n><n>tokenizedText = wordFilter(text)<n># print(tokenizedText)<n>if tokenizedText in wordFilter(text) :<n># if "accomplishing " in ("plumber " in text):<n>	return "You could learn to work "<n>else:<n>	return "You can't learn to play "<n><n><n><n>'''<n>		<n><n>for file in glob.iglob("data/input/input.txt"):<n>	#open file <n>	fobj = open(file,"r")<n>	lines = fobj.readlines()<n><n>	for line in lines:<n>		#extracting words from string <n>		words=line.split() <n><n><n>		# check for specific words<n>		if "plumb" in words:<n>		if "oil" in "plumbing":<n>			print "found one"<n>		print words

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:In the middle of the day what will someone do because of being hungry? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: make bread C: eat in restaurant D: have lunch E: make bread<n><n>### Response:		A: cook dinner<n><n>### Input(Question): At 1:20 AM, what are the chances of getting in an auto accident? Choices:  Mixed numbers:  A: 38% B: 36% C: 40% D: 34% E: 54%<n><n>### Response(Question):At 1:20AM, the chances are the lowest as possible since it is 54%.<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>```<n>Input: Where did Bill find a friend willing to tell his secrets?<n>Chosen Answer: (1:20am) (1:56am) (2:20am)<n>```<n><n>### Concept:<n><n>To complete the task one must write a response in the form of:<n><n>```<n>[The hour the answerer would like to speak to the questioner] [Where the answerer can be found by the questioner]<n>```<n><n>## Solution<n>|Input|Response|Concept|<n>|---|---|---|<n>|Where could you find some plumbering that would not be use to you if you were thirsty?| A: Oil refineries|Answer the Question|<n>|When a person is beginning their day what are they NOT doing?| D: Accomplishing|Answer the Question| <n>|Where Could I find pens with a companys logo on them?| A: Office|Answer the Question|  <n>|What are the chances of an accident at 12:20 in the morning?| D: 40%|Response: "At 12:22 the chances are the higest as possible since it is ____"|  <n>|Where could I find Bill that is willing to tell his secretes? A: 2:05pm, 1:20am, 2:20am, Anywhere or Nowhere|Question: "Where did you find bill at that particular time?"|Answer: "1:20 am!"<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? What plumbing system is made to remove water? <n><n>**Task 2:**<n><n>\What type of plumbign would a person need to do while they are still at rest?<n>What plumbing is made to bring water to us?<n><n>**Task 3:**<n><n>\How will the person have to start with the garden.<n><n>What plumbing would the harvest have?<n><n>### Instructions:In each multiple choice question, there are three true statements and one statement that is wrong.<n><n>Answer that statement. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:What country has with the capital of Amsterdam has a Fortis bank? Choices:  A: netherlands B: utrecht C: brussels D: belgium E: denmark<n><n>### Response:		This problem uses the logical operator<n>```python<n>from math import ceil<n>def ceil_function_x(x):<n>    y = int(ceil(x))<n>    return y<n>```<n><n>### Above is the ceiling function. The function takes an input value and returns the next integer greater than that value.<n><n>To answer this question, we need to find the remainder of the difference of the 232 and 8.<n>We can do this by subtracting 232 from 8<n><n><n>8 - 232 = 164<n><n>8 % 164 = 8 % 2<n>2<n><n>This means the nearest integer to the remainder of 8% of 2 is 1<n>

Choices:  A: heart transplant B: distance himself C: perform surgery D: study medicine E: let blood<n><n>### Response:		Doctor: Let blood.<n><n>### Input 1: Where would you find a candy cane? Choices: A: ice cream shop B: candy store C: grocery store D: cookie platter E: Christmas<n><n>### Response 1: You can find a candy cane at a Christmas tree shop.<n><n>### Comment: You find them in a grocery store too?<n><n>### Input2: Where won't you find a plumbing repair shop? Choices: A, B, C, or D.<n><n>### Response2: You won't find them at a laundromat.<n><n>### Explanation<n>Where might I find pens with the company logo?<n><n>To determine the answer, start at the letter A and work your way through each of the remaining choices to find the answer.<n><n>Starting at A, we see that pens with a company logo would be found in an office. This does not answer the question so we move on to the next choice.<n><n>At the letter B we see that we could find pens with the company's logo written on a pencil. This does fit with the answer so we move on.<n><n>At letter C we see that we could write sentences on paper. This also fits with the answer so we continue.<n><n>At the choice D, "school," we see that we could use paper for writing sentences. This is the correct answer to our question and our response would be answered with a statement of the answer.<n>

A group of men soldiers then walked out, and a crowd of women students followed and hissed him."<n><n>3: 11<n><n>4: <n><n>5:  Yes, yes, they did in "The women who served in the army were as brave as the men who served. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:Why is this person not listening to music? Choices:  A: fall asleep B: relaxation C: deafness D: bored E: calm<n><n>### Response:		<n>When the question says "Why is this person not..." this means the reason must be directly related to their situation. So even though music is a reason to not do something, we can't use it as an appropriate response here.<n><n>You don't always know what is going on by looking at a character, so we should only use what we know about them. If one character can have several conditions that would prevent them from listening to music, then we can't just say "to relax" because we don't know for sure if that is what's preventing them from listening to music (maybe they don't have time to relax, for example).<n><n>Since it's unclear why the person is not listening to music, we'll use one of our best guesses. If there is a chance you could be wrong or off-topic, it's better to avoid an answer. Also note there are many possibilities for why the character may not be listening to music (such as not being able to, not having a way to, or there simply not being music playing currently).<n><n>So, because we don't known what's happening, I'd like to use the most likely reason: the character may not be able to listen to music. This means I'd prefer responses like A-C, where listening to music is not an option for some reason. I chose A.<n><n>### Input:"The company I work for is pretty cool. Not very many people would agree though, which is one way you could tell they are great."<n><n>### Response:"The company I work at is also pretty cool! What is your favourite part of your office? I think mine is the snack machine."<n><n>### Instructions:Add one more response to the question, in addition to any that were already provided.<n><n>### Response 2:<n>Another option to be able to enjoy the snack machine at my office is having our own, and adding more snacks inside!<n><n>### Difficulty:Interpertation, Common sense, Common phrases<n><n>### Reward: 5 Points

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:Where do you keep a teakettle? Choices:  A: cupboard B: countertop C: water D: hardware department E: england<n><n>### Response:		A: cupboard<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Enter a boolean expression (true or false statement) as an answer to each question. If a question has three true statements, then the answer is true. For additional information and examples, read the [Boolean Expressions](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Boolean_expression) section on the Mozilla Developer Network.<n><n>### Example:<n>A: If I were a developer I would like to write in Rust.<n>A: If I went to the store I would not find a book that contained the answer to my question.<n>A: If Tesla had invented the car, everyone would use one.<n>A: I do not like the color red.<n>A: If my computer freezes up I would like to know why.<n>A: If a person does a good job, then that person might be promoted.<n>A: I am doing this at my home, not at the place of work.<n>A: If it were spring time it would be nice outside.<n>A: If water was a planet I would want to live on it.<n>A: If an elephant was a person I would invite it to my birthday party.<n>A: If there was an emergency, I would want to be called to the scene.<n>A: If the world ends tomorrow I would have a sad face.<n><n>#### Input: If I have chicken, then I have mood?<n><n>#### Response: False<n><n>#### Input:If I am walking down the street, then I am not in my home?<n><n>#### Response True<n><n>#### Input:if John wanted to tell you a funny story then he would tell you johnny<n><n>#### Responce:False<n><n>#### Input:john wants to tell you a funneyman he does not want to tell you<n><n>#### Response:True<n><n>#### Input:True<n><n>---<n><n># [Back][1] to top

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:If I take my heifer out East, where's a place we might end up? Choices:  A: new hampshire B: dairy farm C: farm field D: texas E: county fair<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>from random import randint<n>input_data = input()<n>correct_answers = [('A', 'new hampshire'), ('B', 'dairy farm'), ('C', 'farm field'), ('D', 'texas'), ('E', 'county fair')]<n>choice = [input_data]<n>for answer in correct_answers[1:]:<n>    if answer[0] in choice:<n>        output_answer = answer[1]<n>        break<n>else:<n>    output_answer = ''<n>print(output_answer)<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:Where do  you park in the parking lot with shopping bags? Choices:  A: amusement park B: urban area C: airport D: shopping malls E: train station<n><n>### Response:		<n>```js<n>const whereDoYouParkInTheParkingLotWithShoppingBags = (choices = ['amusement park', 'urban area', 'airport','shopping malls', 'train station']);<n>console.log(`Given: ${choices}`, choises);<n>```<n>```js<n>for (let i = 0; i < choises.length-1; i++){<n>  const {value, selected} = choises[i];<n>  console.log(`Value: ${`${value} + selected`}`);<n>  if (choises[i].selected) {<n>    continue;<n>  }<n>}<n>```<n><n><n>### Inputs:<n>```js<n><n>const getParkingWithShoppingBaggage = function(choices);<n>console.log(getParkingWithSohppingBaggage(['amusement park', 'train station']));<n>```<n>```js <n><n>getParkingWithBaggage()<n>   .then((result = null) => {<n>      console.log(result);<n>    }) <n>   .catch(err => console.log(err));<n>```<n><n>### Outputs<n>```<n>Given: [ amusement park, train station ]<n>Value: amusement park + train station == undefined<n>```<n><n>```<n>  <n>```<n><n>## Instructions:Use a template-driven approach  to test some conditions.<n><n>### Input<n>```js<n>// write response in the code below<n>const doNotCleanTheGrass = (lawnArea = 500000, grasArea = 25000, lawnTower = 2000 );<n>```<n><n>## Example:<n><n>### Input 01<n>Input:Do not clean the grass, because it's not my lawn.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>```js<n>let grasArea = 1300;<n>let lawnArea = 27000;<n>let towerArea = 15000;<n><n>console.log(doNotCleanTheGras(lawnArea, grasArea, lawnTower));<n>```<n>### Output<n>```<n>Given do not clean the grass because its not my lawn<n>

Choices:  A: cross street B: milk cow C: lose weight D: step forward E: need food<n><n>### Response:		No<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Because the cow needs someone who knows how to do that<n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:Learning usually leads to greater what? Choices:  A: get to know B: gain knowledge C: intelligence D: education E: gaining knowledge<n><n>### Response:		<n>Learning is a process.<n><n>### Input/Response: What happens after a lesson that you can say good things about it? Choices:  Answer: A: You can use the information to teach others.<n><n>### Comments:<n>You do the work here.<n><n>### Question:What must someone do in order to understand complex tasks? Choices: Answer: A: Read the instructions<n><n>### Comment:<n>You do the instruction-giving.<n><n>### Output:What does working hard mean? Choices: Answer : A: Working harder is not working hard<n><n>### Comment<n>You have to have an idea yourself first and then write this idea into your instructions. You can get the answers from Google and just use them. Also, you should check answers on a different website.<n><n>### Example: <n><n>### Output Example:<n><pre>> What is a good way of completing difficult tasks?  <n>The better you understand the instructions, the better you will do at anything else you have to complete.<n></pre><n><n>### Example 2:<n><n>### Input Example:<n><pre><n>  What are two ways to determine whether information can be understood?<n> </pre><n><n>## Contributing<n><n>How to contribute?<n><n>## Additional Information<n><n>This project is open to anyone to contribute, but it should be an informative, educational-type blog.<n><n>## License<n><n>The MIT License (MIT)<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:Illegitimate designer handbags will not have a certificate of what? Choices:  A: actions B: legal C: authentic D: logical E: legitimate<n><n>### Response:		A: actions<n><n>In the first example in the above instruction, all but choice C are an acceptable response. The problem is C, which says, "a person isn't beginning work yet."<n><n>In the third example, we can eliminate "on a pencil" and "write sentences on paper" because those places are where you might find a company logo, not pens.<n><n>And in the fourth example, we can eliminate C because a certificate would only be "legitimate" if it were for "legal" or "authentic" actions.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:Where can I find a steakhouse with a view of corn fields? Choices:  A: nebraska B: new york C: mexico D: home E: utah<n><n>### Response:		I found a steakhouse in Ne w York that offered a view of corn fields. I have a picture in my phone album.<n><n>### Credit:This task was a contribution from [Grace Kwon @ Grace Kwon](mailto:gracekwon.seunggmi@gmail.com). Thank You for contributing! You can contribute, as well. <n><n>### How to Contribute:<n><n>1. Create a branch in your fork of this repo.<n>2. Copy the example and replace the text or numbers with other variables and text that you want to change. <n>3. You can create and use variables using a variety of different methods. I'll give you a few ideas to get you started:<n>- Use curly brackets with numbers or text to denote what type of data to replace.<n>- Create variables with the key words `$` or `$#` to denote text or numbers.<n>- Use the `rand()` function in JavaScript to create a number that acts like a variable to help create responses based on user input. It takes the format of `rand(0,100)`. <n><n><n>### If you need further help:<n>If you need further help or have questions, email me.<n>You can use the link on my [personal site](https://www.dangnhan.com/).<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:What are people playing when they want to take the lead with small papers? Choices:  A: very heavy B: video game C: news article D: card game E: lead pencil<n><n>### Response:		<n>* If the answer is A, the response should be "On a pencil".<n>* If the answer it B, the response should be.<n>"On or in a video game".<n>* If the Answer is D the response should be "I can't think of a card game where it would be helpful."<n>* If the answer Is E, the response should be:<n>"I can't think if a game that you are taking the lead with is on or in a small paper."<n><n>### Inputs A to D:<n>* Input A:<n>  * A: oil refinerys<n>Response:<n>  A) I don't usually carry oil refinerys.<n>  * B: wall<n>Response:<n>  B) It is possible, but I don't think I could find any oil or the refinery itself.<n>  * C: show<n>Response:<n>  C) I can think of one.<n>  * D: own home<n>Response:<n>  D) If I'm thirsty I wouldn't really want my own home.<n><n>* Input B:<n>  * A B) I don't really know.<n>C) I would only have it when I'm tired from work.<n>  * C) I don't know how to spell'momentum'.  I'd rather just spell it in regular text or by hand."<n>D) I think it's in the text book I'm using for the word "momentum".<n>  * D) It's in the dictionary next to "momentum'<n><n>* Input C:<n>  * A) It would probably not fit in my pocket.  I could put it somewhere though like in my satchel or in my car's glove box in case I lost my satchel, which has not happened yet.<n>  * B) In a car?  That's a new one for me.  I'd have to buy one.<n>  * C). It's hard to read a book when you only get the chance to read part of it. I usually have a break between classes in the middle.<n>  * C. It would never fit on a wall though.  I have some, and they are pretty expensive.<n><n>### Input D:<n>  * A. I'm not even sure what they are.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:Mark wanted to know the truth, because he didn't want to continue existing in what? Choices:  A: understand B: were there C: ignorance D: in-between E: ignorant<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```python<n>#Write a function named 'guess' that takes as input a single statement. <n>#Then, if the statement is a question, print "A" or "B" for the answer, otherwise, print "C" for "None".<n><n>def guess(x):<n>    if(" " in x):<n>        print("C")<n>    else:<n>        if ("?" in x):<n>            print("A")<n>        else:<n>            print("B")<n>        ```<n>### Instruction for 'answer' function:<n><n>```python <n>guess("Where could people find some plumbing?")<n>guess("Where can a person find pens?")<n>guess( "Who is an inventor?")<n>guess ("How does a person make good business decisions?")<n>guess ( "Where should a person take a pencil?")<n>```<n>### Output:<n>```<n>C <n>A<n>A<n>How does a person make?<n>"A" or "B?"<n>```<n>```<n>Guess.py<n>#Write function named ‘answer’ that takes input from the function you named ‘guess’. <n>#Call the answer function like this: [answer(x)]<n><n>answer(guess('Where could people find some'))<n>answer(guess( 'Who is an '<n>))<n>answer(guesses( 'How does a person make'))<n>answer(' Where should a person take a' pencil?)<n>```<n><n>### Output: <n>```<n>C<n>A<n>How does 'A' or 'B' <n>Where should 'A' or 'None'<n>```<n><n>Answer: Write a script named ‘answer’ that calls the function named ‘guess’, then displays the result using the function ‘print’. You can create a new function named ‘answer’, but first you must define it in the following way:<n><n>```python  <n>def answer(*args):<n>   answer = func(*args)<n>```<n><n>Now write a function named ‘guess_yesno_question’ to test your answer_() function. You can create this function just like your answer_() function, but name it 'guess_yesno' instead. <n><n>Finally, call the function 'guess_yes_no_question' to test the program,

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:What is the purpose of the cabin in an airplane? Choices:  A: crash B: living C: slow down D: carry people E: speed up<n><n>### Response:		<n>There is an interesting story behind the development of the cabin. The first airplane that the Wright Brothers made did not have a nose wheel. This meant that the front of the plane rested directly on the ground. With no landing gear, the cockpit was right in front of the pilot. This was not a good design. The Wright Brothers later made a cabin that was enclosed and separated from the cockpit. When the plane was taxiing, the front wheels (called the nose wheel) could be retracted below the surface of the airplane. (from [this](https://www.lucidchart.com/blog/history-of-the-cabin-on-airplanes/))<n><n>### Input :  When might you find the company logo at work? Choices:  in a car A: B: C: D: E:<n><n>Answer: A:<n><n>When traveling.<n><n>### Input  : If you're in a rush, where could you find a place to charge it? Choices: A: school B: office C: fast food D: gas station E: coffee shop<n>Answer: <n>F:<n><n>On a plane<n><n>### Input   : If you work fast at your office job would it have to do with when you work there? Choices:<n><n>Answer:<n><n>F:<n><n>**On a plane**<n><n>

It should take in a string. It should use recursion, and convert the string to one with no capital letters. It should return the new string.<n><n>### Demo:<n>```python<n>def no_capital_letters(letters):<n>    if letters:<n>        letters = letters[1:]<n>        letters = no_capital_letter(letters)<n>        return no_capital_lets(letters)<n>else:<n>    return capital_letters<n>```<n><n>## 1.2: Functions<n><n>### 1:<n>```python<n>print("A function can do some operation on one or more variables as in:")<n>```<n>### 2:<n>```python<n># Write a function that receives a string and prints it<n>def my_print(string):<n>    print(string)<n>```<n>### Demo<n>```python<n>>> my_print("Hello world")<n>Hello world<n>```<n><n>## Demo:<n>    Write a function that receives one or more arguments.<n>    In the arguments, a string will be passed.<n>    In the function call, print the string.<n><n>## 1:<n>``` python<n>def my_print_v1(string_var, n):<n>    print("Hello, I'm " + string_var + ".\nI can choose to be ", n, "\ or ", n, ",\n and I can change my name to ", string_var + n, "\.\n")<n>```<n>## 2:<n>``` python<n># Write a function to return the index of a number, given the number and the range.<n>```<n>## Demo<n>``` python<n>def index_of(n, range):<n>    for i in range(len(range)-1):<n>        if i >= n:<n>            break<n><n>    return i<n>```<n>## Demo:<n>Writing a function

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>Input: Where might I find pens with a company logo? Choices:  A: office B: on a pencil C: write sentences on paper D: school E: backpack<n>Answer: A: office<n><n>### Input:How would someone feel after going for run? Choices:  A: working out B: sore C: get tired D: satisfaction E: falling down<n><n>### Response:		The choices could be arranged differently but here are the examples for each arrangement.<n>```java<n>public static int [][] sort(int [][] matrix) {<n>    int [][] newMatrix= new int[5][5];<n>    for (int k = 0; k < matrix.length; k += 1) {<n>        int [] sortedArray = sort(matrix[k]).toArray();<n>        newMatrix[k] = newArray(sortedArray);<n>    }<n>    return newMatrix;<n>}<n>```<n>```diff<n>+     int [][] sortedarray = newArray(sort(matrix[k]).sort());<n>+     newmatrix[k] = newarray(sortedarray);<n>```<n>```diff2<n>-     sortarray(newmatrix[k]) = newArray(sortMatrix(matrix[k]));<n>```<n>```java2<n>+     sortedarray(newmatrix[i]) = sortMatrix(matrix[i]);<n>```<n><n>### Output: What is the length of "A-B"?<n>```java<n>public class Sort {<n>    public static int [] sort(int [][] array) {<n>        if (array.length < 2) {<n>            return array;<n>        }<n>        //TODO<n>       ...<n>    }<n>   ...<n><n>    public static boolean [][] sort(int a[], int [][] b[]){<n>        for (int i = 0; i < b.length; i++) {<n>            int [][] newb2 = sort(b[i]);<n>            boolean [][] newarray = sortarray(newb2);<n>            a[i] = newarray.array[i];<n><n>        }<n>        return b;<n>    }<n>        //sortarray(newarray.sort()) = array;<n>    }<n><n>    public static integer [] newArray (int [] array) {<n>        var newArray = new IntegerArray (array);<n>        return newArray.sort().array;<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n>Output:<n>```java<n>  | a | b | c | d | e | f |<n>  |   |   |   | 0 | 0 | 1 |<n>  |  0 |  1 |  1 |  0 |  0 |<n>  |  1 |  2 |  1 |  3 |  2 |<n>  |

The answer is 2 because the max is a value of 6 and an value is 5 and b value 6.<n><n>### Response3:<n>1. The maximum number of apples that you can add, is 4.<n>2. The maximum number of fruits that you can eat is 2.<n><n>### Note:<n>The question asks, what is the maximum number of ____ that you can add.<n><n>### Discussion:<n><n>* In real life, you might have 5 apples in your tummy and add a new fruit to eat.<n>* An apple is not fruit because fruit can either be eaten, cut or taken and it is not the value of an fruit, that we are interested in.<n><n>### Challenge 1:<n>Give the solution only.<n><n>### Solution:<n>* Give a full solution<n><n>### Challenge Response 1:<n>* Give a valid response and justify it with a reason.<n>* 1.
